reviewText: R.I.P.P.E.D. is a solid workout and like the description says it's a "one stop shop". One can opt to play each workout individually or as a 50 minute workout.There is also a bonus ab section that's not part of the routine. The reason I am giving it 4 stars instead of 5 is there is just something missing. I think it's a combination of the cheesy music that's made for the workout and the routine itself. While it's a good workout and it will remain in my rotation, I'm just not having as much fun as the fitness folks in the DVD.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: This has become my favorite workouts. The workouts include enough variety so it isn't boring. It is easy to follow although it does have a tutorial option. The segments transition easily. And, it is just the right length of time to fit into my morning workout routine. I really like both lead trainers. It has modifications for lower impact. But, it is still a strong workout. A good solid workout for all levels.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I'm always on the lookout for a new DVD to keep my workout challenging and to keep boredom from setting in.  Sometimes I find a great DVD and after a month it loses its appeal no matter how much I loved it to start.  I thought RIPPED would be a great new addition.  After using it for two weeks, there are some definite bonuses, but it's not my favorite.  I don't think it will last long in my lineup.Things I liked:  The starting menu has a place to select whether you want the beginner's instruction to the exercises or to just play through.  It's handy.  I did enjoy the instruction the first few times, but after that I found the break in routine to explain everything unnecessary, so it's nice to be able to deselect it.  It's nice to see modifications as well.  This video has someone doing more low-impact and someone doing more high-impact.  I also liked that it paired cardio with weights in one DVD, and had smooth transitions throughout.Things I didn't like:  Cheesy huge fake smiles and lots of "OK!' and "Super!"  It was really off-putting to me.  I love a positive, motivational attitude in a workout DVD, but this was so far over the top it was irritating.  When explaining exercises in the tutorial, each person is introduced as "the wonderful Wanda" or "the amazing Tina".  I could have done without that.
summary: Not my favorite, but a solid workout
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: This is an excellent workout program to mix in with other workout programs. It's upbeat and definitely does a good job of giving a great aerobic workout. The introduction does a good job of giving a preview of what the program is about. The Workout Options is the main program. it's a 48 minute program without the tutorials. With the tutorials, it's a 65 minute program. There's also the option of an additional 5 minute ab workout. Of course you have the option to run through the program with or without tutorials.The program is run by a husband and wife team who do a great job of keeping the program interesting and explaining the exercises.  When exercising with weight or aerobic workouts, form is very important. Each section includes tutorials on proper form and movements for each of the exercises. The tutorials add 2 to 4 minutes per section.  The program starts with 5 min warm up to loosen the muscles and then gets into the five different sections, plus the cool down, and then the bonus abs section. The diet and nutrition is just a slide on information, but you can obtain much more information regarding diet from their website.The only things you need are some light free weights/dumb bells. Even in the Power section, dumbbells are only used for 3 minutes. You also need a towel for the ab section.The program is excellent. I haven't used too many programs because I like to create my own workouts, so i can't compare with others, but this is just as fun as a few classes I have taken at my gym. The music is generic, upbeat music that helps keep you motivated. This is definitely one workout to throw into the mix each week or every two weeks to keep things fresh.Any program like this really just keeps you moving for 30 to 45 minutes, while altering exercises. And it's that constant movement that keeps your heart rate up.  If you don't exercise regularly, take classes, or do any of these types of workouts, I highly recommend you really take your time and develop the form correctly. Start slowly and you don't need to keep up the first few times. You can hurt yourself, pull a muscle, or weaken your joints if you do the exercises incorrectly. So just watch the lead in any program and develop your form correctly.  You also need to learn how to breathe properly to be able to last longer without getting tired. Exhale upon exertion and keep breathing steady.
summary: Excellent workout program to add to the mix.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: Got this video to spice up and have more variety in my exercise regimen. I already have yoga, Pilates, Callanetics and dance exercises that I alternate through every 6 weeks when my body got used to them. RIPPED Total Body Challenge is a total body workout that goes through several different exercises in 48 minutes, from low to high intensity to resistance and weights and includes diet advice, too.RIPPED stands for resistance, intervals, power, plyometrics, endurance, and diet [and nutrition]. When I first started this exercise, I knew I wouldn't be able to do it everyday for the first 2 weeks, only because it's not what my body is used to. So I knew I had to take it slowly. So I alternated RIPPED Total Body Challenge on M-W-F with yoga and Pilates on T-Th-S (with swimming on Sat). After 2 weeks, I felt I had enough endurance and strength to ramp it up to 4 days a week, then 5. I still go through a 15-minute stretch with either yoga/Pilates and Callanetics before going through RIPPED, only to make sure my muscles are loose and not tight. However, RIPPED does have a warmup portion at the beginning, which you can do in lieu of a stretching warmup. The exercises go through each stage of RIPPED with low- and high-intensity exercises. Tina and Terry Shorter also have some exercisers doing the modified (easy) version so you can follow that if you're just starting out with this; others do the regular version; and 2 exercisers do the ramped up version. Each of the exercises eventually get your heart rate up. There are pauses in between where they explain the upcoming exercises, and at these points I sometimes take a drink of water or count my pulse to see if I'd reached maximum heart rate for optimum cardiovascular benefit, depending on the exercise that came before.  (The plyometrics especially are good for me as I swim a mile once a week in the winter and 3 days a week in the spring, summer and fall.)  As with the other exercise videos I got from Amazon, this is well worth the price. It is a well-rounded, complete exercise program that addresses everything your body needs to be fit and toned, strong and powerful. I highly recommend this to anyone who wants to lose or maintain weight, build endurance and strength and power, and tone or build muscles, accompanied by good diet and nutrition.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: The R.I.P.P.E.D. workout program was created by husband and wife team Terry and Tina Shorter.  In their introduction, they explain that R.I.P.P.E.D.--or Resistance, Intervals, Power, Plyometrics, Endurance, and Diet and Nutrition--was designed to put the "fun" in functional training, in part through the use of all original music.  (On their web site, the information about Terry Shorter reveals that he has a background in music/entertainment and that he performs all the music on the DVD, with Tina and their daughter Tawnie on background vocals).The Main Menu of this DVD offers the following options:  Introduction - Workout Options -Bonus Features (information about the founders) - Also from Acacia - Credits.  The Workout Options submenu brings up the chapters and times as I have listed below, although I have added additional details.  Where a "Y/N" is indicated, there is the option of playing a tutorial, which includes longer explanations of the moves (note that this does slow down the workout).  Tony and Tina take turnings teaching live in a large brick studio with eight background exercisers.  One of those exercisers, Beth, shows modifications, including lower impact, and another performs some more advanced moves.  This routine requires dumbbells as well as a towel for the bonus abs segment.PLAY ALL (48 min)...Y/NWARM UP (6 min)Terry leads the warm-up, which includes some kettlebell-inspired movements such as punches, dynamic stretching, and higher-impact moves including split runs and jumping jacks.  The sequence is repeated several times.RESISTANCE (7 min)...Y/NHere Tina leads strength training for the upper body only.  She performs bicep curls to the front and side, shoulder raises to the front and side, and then triceps dips on the floor; the entire series is repeated once.  Only one set of dumbbells is used by the group, but most people will want a different weight for biceps versus shoulders.INTERVALS (5 min)...Y/NThis cardio intervals segment is also led by Tina.  Using an imaginary jump rope, she starts with heels front, first slow, then sped up.  She also moves feet in/out and high knees forward and back.  Additional moves including fast feet (making quarter turns and coming full circle), squat jacks, and a brief freestyle.  The sequence is repeated several times.POWER (10 min)...Y/NTerry returns to led the power segment; he states that the larger, metabolic muscles are worked here.  The main move is a pulsing squat/plié that is repeated throughout--Terry notes that there are a total of 128 squats (I believe there are five sets).  The squats/plié combo is followed by slow burpees.  There is also a plank with leg shift, plank with rotation, push-ups, and two rounds of reverse flyes/pistons.PLYOMETRICS (5 min)...Y/NTina is back for another cardio-based section.  The foundational move is a single-single-double quarter turn followed by a "hit the floor" alternating lunge; Tina returns to this brief sequence again and again.  Next comes a side-to-side fancy footwork pattern.  The remaining moves were a bit more plyo-based, including a "jump off" front-back side-to-side hop and a squat to jump.ENDURANCE (10 min)...Y/NIn the intro, Tony, who instructs this section, states that it consists of three mixed-martial arts (MMA) based segments.  There is actually one kickboxing sequence that is repeated throughout (a single-single-double punch, knee to either side, hook to either side), and then three other distinct patterns: 1) a classic boxing combination performed on either side, 2) a capoeira-inspired part that includes jenga and front kicks, and 3) a more MMA-feel sequence with punches down and burpees with knees.DIET & NUTRITIONThis link pulls up a screen with some very basic information--e.g., the recommendation to consume a balance of protein, carbohydrates, and fat--and a referral to the R.I.P.P.E.D. web site.COOL DOWN (5 min)Tony moves through a sequence of stretches and Tai Chi-like flows.  He starts with a calf stretch and front triangle, moves into a focus on a "ball of energy," stretches the quads, performs more flows, and finishes with upper body stretches.BONUS ABS (5 min)This is a 5.5-minute standing core work segment led by Tina; it is not included in the "Play All" selection.  She holds a towel in her hands, and she repeats a side-to-side crunch throughout.  The other moves include alternating knees front, bringing the towel to the shins; knees to one side; and using the towel to perform a row.Those who enjoy a mix of cardio and strength all in one DVD are a good audience for this workout.  It is a solid intermediate level, although it is geared more towards keeping the heart rate up than providing a challenging strength workout.  The music is high energy yet also self-promoting (i.e., the name of the workout and tag line "one stop body shock" are both repeated throughout).  However, those who enjoy R.I.P.P.E.D. classes at the gym are likely to appreciate this DVD, and it should appeal to other at-home exercisers as well.
summary: Solid intermediate workout offering both cardio and strength intervals
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I haven't rowed for two months so I was curious about this 48 minute video that promised an intense cardio/resistence/plyometric  workout.  Several other reviewers have detailed the specific content with remarkable detail, so I won't go through all that here.It isn't nearly as intense as the name implies, but it's very well done and easy to follow.  I can increase the intensity with full extension, better form, and/or higher weight.  As a man who doesn't do many of these cardio DVDs, it has taken me a while to learn and get entirely comfortable with some of the moves, which aren't at all out of the ordinary, but I need to be able to do them without being challenged to keep up.The overall theme is pleasant, a modest amount of personality, a good variety of actors, music is average, but the variety of exercise is perfect for me. All you need is a dumbbell and a little patience.  Its primary strength for me is the ease with which it has helped me get active again.  Not intimidating (except for some of the footwork!) at all.  Excellent for beginners.
summary: Good Intro to Cardio Workout For Beginners
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewerName: Book Sake "A Book Review & Contests Blog"
reviewText: I like that the instructions on how-to do the workout moves is separate from the actual workout portion of the video - however they are doing it at the same speed and not really explaining anything.  Good idea, poor execution.The workout portions are separated as well, so if you only wan to do one 5 minute workout you can.  The personalities of the trainers aren't as big and engaging as some of the more famous trainers, so that falls flat.  There is a modifier for a slower, easier version and a faster, harder version, which was unique and that was something I really liked - unfortunately you can see all versions - slow, regular, fast at the same time.
summary: Like the Moves, Would LIke Bigger Personalities
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge was not what I expected. I hadn't heard of the program before and so I didn't know what to expect but this workout is well rounded and incorporates a lot of additional principals than most workout videos. I like to have motivation and variety of movements so I don't get bored and turn it off and this did deliver that. Although I personally didn't like all the music and the botox frozen smiles so much, I did enjoy the fast upbeat energy of the program. Some moves are not tolerable with a bad back like burpees, but there are alternative modification moves you can do instead. They state that this video is for a fitness buff or beginner, but honestly it's more intermediate. Personally, I would like to see them tone down their focus on stage presence and focus more on being real.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: This DVD makes an excellent addition to any workout library/gym.  The best thing about it is that they show you how to modify it to be harder, or how you can modify it to be easier.  You can also, at the main menu, choose what section of the workout you want to do and whether or not you want the tutorial before each section to play, also.  I LOVE this workout and would recommend it to anyone who is looking to get in a good and fun sweaty workout!
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I got this as a Vine Review & sure glad I did.  The instructors are great & don't over talk like so many others; the exercises are not boring & there is a modifier & advanced person you can watch.  I like the squats that go from feet parallel to sumo squat with an easy transition; modification for burpees & a good standing ab section. This DVD is good for all levels; I follow Beths modifications & still get a great workout.  I certainly hope Terry & Tina (husband & wife) follow up with more quality workout DVDs.  Buy it, you will love it.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: This workout regiment is not as hard core as the name suggests. Ripped is the acronym for resistance, intervals, power, plyometrics, endurance and diet/nutrition. It is a good mix up of warm up and good resistance training, fat burning, etc. The participants are in fantastic shape (I envy the women's arms). I have difficulty with coordination and balance and had to skip a couple exercises in the warm up routine until I get better at it, but I love the upbeat movements and variety. They are warm up moves I'm not familiar with, but I like something new. I also like the choices of a modified version or advanced. They have people doing both so you can follow the variation that best suits your capabilities. I didn't care for some of the more modern music, but they have a good mix so you don't listen to one type of music throughout and it wasn't anything intolerable. I think this is good for a wide variety of age groups, but perhaps a little too advanced in areas for seniors. They may not have the coordination, and unless they have remained in great shape all their lives, may end up hurting themselves. I also loved the mix of martial arts style movements in one segment of the tape. Again, they were movements I was not familiar with so it took me a little while to catch on, but once I did I found them to be a fun, new workout that I have not seen in other workout videos or at the gym. They have added a tutorial demonstration for form that really helps people like myself who are not very coordinated or balanced. I feel the workout will help me improve balance over time. There is also an added Abs bonus workout that I like. I was expecting a more hard core video, but in the end I was happy it wasn't. This is a good balance between beginner and slightly more modified fitness. This will help me have fun staying in shape on those days where it is too icy on the roads to get in to the gym, or I only have an hour to squeeze in between errands on a really busy day.
summary: Not hard core, but great workout
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: This review was written with the expert input of my little sister, exercise superstar and fitness-video aficionado. I myself am a student of the lazy-person school of exercise.R.I.P.P.E.D is marketed like a kind of wimpy-gal's P90X, for those too "intimidated" by intense workout programs. It's your standard stuff: free weights, cardio, kicking and punching around, with a bonus ab workout (The "D" in R.I.P.P.E.D stands for "Diet and Nutrition", but there's no info on the actual DVD--you have to go online for that). I was hoping for an effective yet easy to pick-up routine that would benefit both me and my sister. What we got was a far less effective DVD than the ones we already own, with dubious claims and obnoxious "original" music. Read on for the deets:The DVD claims you will burn 750-1000 calories during the full workout. Now, calorie burn is notoriously elastic; how many calories you will burn in an hour varies greatly depending on a number of factors, including your weight. My sister, who very regularly does 1000 calorie work-outs, was particularly scornful of R.I.P.P.E.D's number claim. The Mayo Clinic website states that high-intensity aerobics for one hour by a 160 lbs. person will only burn about 533 calories. The R.I.P.P.E.D workout did not seem even that level to us (What will net you 800+? Jump roping for a solid hour. No thanks!). Sis felt the tutorials (optional) were silly and unnecessary, but I actually liked them as I am always interested in maintaining correct form and usually have no idea what I'm doing.The workouts themselves are not particularly fun (I really hated the music) and you will find better versions on other DVDs. Take, for example, the bonus ab workout. "You see this sequence?" my sister asked me, while the female instructor was bobbing around with a towel pulled taught between her arms, "Jillian Michaels has you do the same thing. WITH WEIGHTS." I reviewed the nutritional information off the R.I.P.P.E.D. website; it seems pretty harmless and basic. Eat small meals throughout the day, mix of proteins, fats, carbs, eat your veggies, you know the drill. For total beginners to the world of healthy eating it might be a revelation, but for most of you nothing new I suspect.In the end, we didn't really like it. What will get you R.I.P.P.E.D.? Sis says do Jillian Michaels "30-Day Shred". What will get you toned if you're lazy and don't want to go anywhere near Jillian? I like Gaiam's "Pilates Lower Body Workout". Makes my legs look great after just 6 workouts, and it couldn't be more laid-back.As for R.I.P.P.E.D.?GRADE: COn the credits, one background R.I.P.P.E.R says she got in shape for climbing Mount Kilimanjaro. "Not with this workout," my sister scoffed.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: The title makes this workout sound like something that will kill you about 5 minutes into the workout....not so....This workout was great on a number of fronts....engaged group of exercisers who seem to enjoy the workout, maybe that is because someone picked some decent music to play to get you amped up to work out.  Not too loud, not too soft, but enough to get you up and moving.  The segments are short and you can play them with an introduction/tutorial or just straight through....play all of the segments or after you play one it will take you back into the menu where you can choose another workout.  Nicely done!  No wasted time going through the same warm-up or tutorial if you don't need it.The exercises range from resistance, endurance, plyometrics, aerobic, and some boxing moves.A nice range of different types of exercises, and you can choose something just 10 minutes long or string them together how you would like.I exercise every day and really enjoyed it.  I also thought it was great that they included a modifier to show how to do lower intensity versions, if you are a beginner, as I would say this dvd is more in the intermediate category.Overall, a good workout and something different to add in to my weekly mix of workouts.
summary: 48 minutes of varied exercise to keep your muscles guessing....
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: Somehow I feel this was over-marketed to those who are looking for "more" in a workout.  I don't know, call me crazy.  Perhaps it's the slick looking "R.I.P.P.E.D" title, or the promise to burn over "700 calories" that got me interested.  In reality, after doing Insanity, Insanity Asylum, T25 and even P90X, this workout doesn't do much for me.I'm not saying it won't do much for you...just know that if you've done some what I call hardcore workouts before this one, it might just be a disappointment.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: This is a great 48-minute (53 if you add the bonus core section) cardio & strength workout.  The breakdown is: Warm Up (6 minutes); Resistance (7 minutes); Interval (5 minutes); Power (10 minutes); Plyometrics (5 minutes); Endurance (10 minutes); Cool Down (5 minutes); and Bonus Abs (5 minutes.)  There is an option to play with or without tutorials; these times are without tutorials.  If you add tutorials, the total time is roughly 65 minutes.  The tutorial is not really necessary unless you are an ABSOLUTE beginner, since they do the moves first at half-time before bringing it up to tempo.  The Resistance portion uses weights; the Interval section is cardio; Power uses weights again; Plymometrics is cardio again; and Endurance is a series of martial arts moves (jabs, punches, kicks, etc.)  The Bonus Abs section was all standing ab work, and I would have liked it being part of the main workout; the workout would still have clocked in under 60 minutes.  The music in this workout is really great!  The instructors are friendly and their instruction is good; they take turns leading different sections for even greater variety.  Definitely a winner!
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I work out with a Boot Camp class three times a week, So I have actually done most of the exercises from this video and I will attest to their validity. In a way tho' I feel that there is some misunderstanding with this video. Terry & Tina Shorter are the husband and wife trainer team that put R.I.P.P.E.D together (R.I.P.P.E.D stands for Resistance, Intervals, Power, Plyometrics, Endurance, and Diet and Nutrition - yes, it was a stretch to put this acronym together.) and it sounds like they are putting out a greater product than it is.This is in fact one single 48 minute workout with an additional 5 minute abs workout that breaks down into 3 to 5 minute segments  of the aforementioned title which covers upper/lower body, core development and strength training, endurance, and cardio as well as a brief touch base on diet and nutrition. It is basically cliff notes for Cross-Fit.I felt that as a single workout this is fine, and I also enjoyed that it had an alternate viewing option that included segments where they provided clear instruction and visual to perform the more elaborate exercises correctly. In fact I feel that was the most important part, most exercise videos just throw it out there and expect a person to follow precisely. This just does not happen, particularly when an individual is new to the process or when the muscles begin to fatigue. This adds another 20 minutes to the workout and I applauded this element to the video.That being said, it is only one workout and does not provide the rotations that the full on Cross Fit, PX90 and Insanity puts out. In fact to avoid boredom I would recommend this video be rotated in with two or three others within a week to provide a varied workout.There were also a few things I did not care for.The music is terribly distracting. I tried to adjust my audio but there was nothing I could change, the music is techno-hiphop and played at such a decibel that it was often difficult to hear instruction over the beat. It also seemed that, like most exercise tapes this was choreographed to near perfection. I say near because whenever there was an awkward stumble it was because the performers were trying to match movement to an irregular beat. Hiphop might work for the odd bit in a workout, but when listening to music while exercising variety is key. So is being able to clearly hear your instructor.As in any exercise video there were modifications for advanced and beginner. This was performed by Erin (advanced) and Beth (beginner). The problem is that with two instructors in the middle and everyone needing a certain amount of space to perform, Erin and Beth were often cut out of the frame due to camera angles. Not being able to follow them the whole time actually emphasizes the need and importance of the tutorial segments.And lastly, I have watched a LOT of exercise videos and I am well aware that in 95% of them the extras are chosen for level of fitness and attractiveness and this one is no different. However - I have never seen a video where every single participant smiled as manically as they do here and despite the fact that yes, they are all very fit it is also clear that with the exception of the two in the back, plastic surgery really played a hand here. I do not appreciate seeing so much emphasis on the results of a surgeons knife in a fitness video.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: This is a great workout! My wife and I both use it regularly and we have seen results. We've both lost weight and toned up more than we expected; over a 2 month period. It really is a high intensity workout and may not be the place where someone drastically out of shape would want to start. That said, anyone that is in at least moderate physical condition can probably do most or all of it right from the start. The key to the best results is regularity.Personally, when I'm working (say, at my computer), I'll give myself a 10 second countdown. When I reach zero, I go start a RIPPED workout and just do it! I don't allow myself any excuses. Ultimately, it works if you do it!The people that put this together clearly had a vast knowledge of fitness. The workouts will build endurance, strength, and will definitely help you to lose weight; if that is your goal.Highly Recommended!
summary: Really excellent, especially considering the price
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: This exercise DVD is excellent for those already in pretty good shape.  But for beginners, take it slowly.  The exercises must be approached slowly or you will end up with pulled muscles or soreness.  But the directions are easy to follow and I liked that the hosts explained the exercises and made it easy to follow them.However, working up to their level of fitness is going to take awhile, and this is perhaps not the best DVD for a rank beginner.  That being said, I would recommend it.
summary: I will love it as soon as I can do it
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: As of this review - the video cost 9.49.That is a good value if you are looking for an exercise video that you can put into your rotation.I myself, would not want to watch this more than once or twice a week as the location (a drab studio) and the instructors, while not as annoying as some I've watched, do have a tendency to get on the nerves. - Totally off subject, I found it hard to believe the lead guy and girl are married. He seems very feminine. Which leads me to wonder...how "authentic" are these instructors? I generally love people that are true to their nature and that often shines through and makes me really like that person and want to watch them. But when they seem to be pretending to be someone they aren't, it totally ruins the experience for me. Like Bob from Biggest Loser...though he didn't advertise his personal life, he embraced his unique personality (does that make sense?) I felt the instructors were..not really sincerely enthusiastic about exercise...I felt it was more about making money than a sincere desire to use their passion for profit.Anyway, that's totally a personal preference.That being said, I do think it's a good value DVD for the price.The good things: You can choose to do the whole routine or you can break it up into sections. And you can choose to learn the moves first (there is a Y/N) in front of each section.Under the "Diet" section, it simply directs you to their website, which is a bit of a let down and takes you out of the video by asking you to jump on line...and lends to the "this is just about making money" idea.The music was...odd. Some songs were okay, but others were...like...odd romantic jazz.The RIPPED is  kinda ridiculous.the R really arms - not resistance.The I is intervals and there is one step combination that seems even confusing to the people in the video. This section might be a bit tricky for those who have little or no experience in aerobics classes.the Power and Plyometrics are basically legs/bum (lower body) moves.The Endurance is really mostly boxing moves.But it is always good to shake things up and add something new to your routine for muscle confusion, and after you learn the moves, I think this would do the job.All in all, if you're just looking for something new and don't have much money to spend, I don't think this is horrible, but I don't wouldn't hop on line to plaster my social media sites and tell people, "OMG, you MUST get this!!"
summary: Just Didn't Feel Authentic, But Good Value For Price
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: * Great full body workout in a 48-minute time frame* I was sore the first week for sure and I'm a pretty active guy* Agree with other reviewers that the soundtrack/music is well composed* Even the Shaun T Insanity workout is a fairly repetitious workout (same kind of lower-body interval moves...on every workout). But Insanity mixes up lots of the same kind of movements (variations) across multiple days, which creates the perception that you're getting a different workout, when you aren't.I think they could have easily added in two more R.I.P.P.E.D. workouts (3 a week minimum) to add some variety and make the home user think they are doing a different workout when they are simply doing variations of the same moves. Hope that makes sense.* Instructors are clear and give you plenty of warning for the next move. Thank you instructors!!* The price point of $13 isn't bad.But since I can get 10 workouts in Supreme 90 for as low as $20 (i've heard stories of $10 at Target)...things become more competitive for space on my video shelf and if I'll spend the time actually using the workout DVD.* You need to go online to get access to the eating plan and other resources NOT included on the disc or in the DVD case as a handout/insertOVERALL: Worth adding to the other videos in my home exercise collection.
summary: A bit repitious, but excellent workout
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: Before I had kids I loved to do every type of group fitness class from Spinning to yoga to Body Pump to good old 80's step. I also did Thai Boxing (the contact kind) for a couple of years. I love to work out and need to be able to do it at home. This DVD does everything right for me.The menu lets you pick segments individually, with or without a tutorial before hand. You can check your form and learn the moves so when you work out you are paying attention to your body, not craning your neck at the tv trying not to fall down. You can do the whole video at once, again with or without tutorials. The straight work out is around 50 minutes, if you play it with the tutorials it's just over an hour. Some folks have complained that the change from one section to the next makes it seem disjointed, but I like the opportunity to take a sip of water, roll my shoulders, and set up for the next challenge.I am so grateful everyone seems to have correct form while doing the moves! Everyone's body position looked good for all the weight work, squats, push ups, etc. I have a special grudge against videos that use incorrect martial arts form. It's not dance class, people. You're not going to learn Capoeira or Muay Thai watching this DVD, but you won't be cringing if you have those in your background either.The blend of the music and cueing is perfect. I can't stand when the music and the steps are off from each other. You can tell the group was listening to the same music you are, sometimes you even catch someone singing along. I do that at the gym too :)Love the energy, love the variety of body types among the in-shape participants, love this workout.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: If you like a bit of everything in your workouts (upper body/lower body/plyo/kickboxing) in short segments, this workout might be worth a try.  If you like Chalene's Turbo Jam workouts, the kickboxing section and warm up on this workout is very similar (I believe at least one of the leads was a back up exerciser in a few of the TJs).  I didn't feel that chest and back were worked enough (pushups and burpees are fine, but I like chest presses or flys in addition).There is a modifier for all high impact moves and I did appreciate the fact that they showed the modifier frequently.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: As a caveat, I completed the P90X program a few years ago, and I judge products like this one against that. That being said, while the P90X workouts focus (for the most part) on one part of the body (e.g., legs and back, abs), this RIPPED workout is more of an overall workout. Instead of an hour dedicated to one group of muscles, this one takes you from one to another to another in short (~5min) segments. You get into it just in time for them to change to a different area to focus on. It keeps you from getting bored or repeating the same moves multiple times, and it has some flexibility and rudimentary instruction for each segment that allows you to get it right and adjust for your own abilities and limitations. It has a bonus ab workout, also five minutes, which is really too limited to make a difference (P90X got it right with Ab Ripper X) but is okay for those trying to maintain rather than improve or tone. This is a decent workout, and it certainly is a nice change of pace from longer, single focus workouts.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: RIPPED is a great way to burn a lot of calories in not a lot of time. I'm not one for exercise videos but I found this one to be very enthusiastic and I was able to keep up. Not for the faint of heart, however. More than "sweating to the oldies". I enjoyed this video very much.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: This workout was interesting. Apparently, there are classes that one can take from this brand but I had never heard of them. This is a husband and wife team. Although they are married, it seems more like it's a woman and her son leading the workout because the wife's demeanor is significantly more serious than that of her husband.The first thing to note is that the music is all original. It ranges from some type of hip-hip/electronic fusion to 80's style go-go to R&B-style; ballad. So, if you are picky about your workout music, you could really like it or really hate it. I appreciated it because after you do as many workout DVD's as I have, you start to hear the same stock music over and over again.There is a pretty solid warm-up in the beginning that pretty much covers the bases in terms of the muscle groups and also provides some light stretching. The husband directs the warm-up section and takes the time to point out the two women who are modifying the moves either way (harder and easier). The warm-up has its moments where it's a little dancy but it should be a problem for even the most dance-challenged exerciser. This is about 6 minutes long.The "R" section is a nice arm workout. I should mention that it appears that repetition is a predominant feature throughout this workout. This works for the "R" section because part of an effective resistance workout is muscle fatigue. Whether or not you'll feel that fatigue depends on what level you are but the areas covered are the biceps, shoulders, and triceps. Be prepared to go to the floor, as one of the moves is the old-school dip for the triceps. The wife leads this section. The amusing part of this section is the young man in the back who is really serious about singing along as he works out. Maybe he's the one on the track? This section is about 7 minutes long.The "I" section is also lead by the wife. It's supposed to be the interval section. It starts really low and slowly builds throughout the rotation. It goes into this "freestyle" section where two of the exercises choose to do some type of deuling air guitar thing while everyone else does more serious exercise but to each his own. The thing to note about the "I" section is that if you are used to more athletic-style intervals, you may find this style a little odd. This section is about 5 minutes long.The first "P" is for power. You will need weights. Please note that if you are squat averse, you may take some issue with this section. The husband notes that in this section, you'll be completing about 128 squats (regular and plie-style). This section also includes push-ups where the feet change position in between (pendulum) and push-ups with trunk rotation. Burpees and mountain climbers are also a feature in this section. This section also goes into a pretty solid back workout (reverse flies and bent rows). Again, this workout has a lot of repetition so you'll do this more than once. According to my timer, this section is about 10 minutes long.The second "P" is for plyometrics. The wife leads this section. It's a little more dancy and some of the moves are reminiscent of a hip-hop class I took when I was in 5th grade. The bulk of it involves football style drills and something they call "the jump-off" (chuckle). Towards the end, they incorporate jump squats and this little bounce where the husband takes the time to do the "jump on it" dance from The Fresh Prince of Bel Air when Will and Carlton were pretending to be strippers. This section is about 5 minutes long.The "E" is for endurance and this section is very heavy on martial arts/kickboxing principles. There are various punch combinations involved. Then, they incorporate some capoeira moves. Burpees are also a part of this section. This section is about 10 minutes long.There is a cool down after this part that's almost 5 minutes long.The "D" is for diet and that's basically them giving you a website to visit.There's a bonus abdominal workout where they are using resistance bands and it's 100% standing ab work. It's about 5 minutes long.A major tip I would give is to make sure that when you go to the menu, that you choose "N" when it asks if you want to play all. If you choose "Y", you will have to sit through several heart rate lowering explanation segments between the actual workout segments where they show you how to do the predominant moves for each section. You may need that and if so, that's cool. However, this workout is full of so much repetition that you'd likely catch on pretty quickly.The main caveat for someone like myself is the repetition. This isn't the kind of repetition that you'd find in a Tabata-style workout or even a plain HIIT workout. This repetition can get boring because it's not as adrenaline-inducing.At the price, I'd say it's a decent find. If I have to put it up against something Michelle Dozois' Peak 10 workouts, it would lose but I could see this as a good workout for someone who is trying to transition from a beginner-level workout regimen to a more intermediate one.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: Usually exercise videos get boring after a while because it's the same thing you're watching over and over again. I've done my fair shair of those and ended up quitting after a week or two.With the Total Body Challenge, maybe it's just me wanting to actually do this program, but I actually had a lot of fun. I liked that I was sweaty at the end, my face was flushed, and I could feel my heart pumping -- and that's me as a beginner probably doing about half of what the people on the video were doing.I'm looking forward to improving as the days go by and soon matching the video move for move.Again, this is not necessarily for beginners. I had a hard time keeping up with the video but I believe that will come in time (it's part of my personal challenge!).What I really appreciate it that they take the time to show you proper form so you're not just flailing up and down, side to side.On top of the workout, there's a separate one for abs.You'll need some weights or resistance band.I live in an older apartment building so my neighbors didn't appreciate all the thumping and jumping up and down. This would work best if you lived in your own home or lived on the first floor.Bottom line: A solid workout -- if you do it right!
summary: Intense, fun, but not for someone starting out
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: At around $20, RIPPED is a good intermediate or even beginner workout video.  It's a similar format to Insanity, but is cheaper because its only one workout versus a series of workouts.  They are all exercises you can do at home.  The workout can be done all at once or you can pick and choose what parts you want to do.  It is fairly interesting--it even kept our 3 year old somewhat engaged.  A cheaper and less intense version of Insanity.
summary: A Good Intermediate Workout Video at the Right Price
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I don't like the DVD very much. First, I think there are very silly movements that add duration but don't work your body. Second, most of the movements are very basic (like standing biceps curls). The abs extra session is totally stupid, 80% comprised of lateral bends which have been demonstrated to be a bad movement for the body. I do not recommend this DVD.
summary: Basic and not very time efficient
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: These videos are well done, and the workouts are genuine workouts taking advantage of interval training techniques with some light resistance training as well . No matter how in shape or out of shape you are, if you do these workouts as described you will be tired and get a workout. The workout was good.  RIPPED stands for Resistance, Intervals, Power, Plyometrics, Endurance, and Diet. This video covers the RIPPE portion, which provides for a good multidemensional workout. It's sorta like P90X stuff just less intense and less intimidating. I appreciate that this isn't all aerobics, or all dumbbell, or all plyo stuff. It's a good rotation through each that keeps it fresh and tiring. I'm glad I have it on my workout rotation.The videos are pretty well done, but they do feel a little bit like my mom's old aerobics videos, cheesy smiles and all. I wish that the music was better and louder, instead it is sort of annoying and in the background. For future videos, maybe two optional soundtracks would be better, one with actual loud music to help keep going and another with no music just words so I can use my own.
summary: Good Workout in Above Average Videos
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I am nowhere near as fit as I once was and my knowledge of exercise is becoming old and dusty.  As I try to get back into shape, I thought some exercise videos might help break up the exercise routine a bit.  After reading about RIPPED, I thought it might be something I would like to try.I will not waste time giving the background on what RIPPED is.  To me, an exercise video serves two purposes, to instruct and help motivate.  The million dollar question to me is does this video to this?I am not a trainer and I will even go as far to say my knowledge of exercises is limited.  Many of these moves I could not even tell you if the instructors demonstrated correctly.  However, in my opinion, most things were demonstrated well enough for me to do them.  The part I did not care for was the endurance section.  In my youth, I was a martial arts fighter.  When I viewed the tutorial for the endurance portion, I thought the portion involving the punching techniques could have been explained much better.  What I thought would have been highly beneficial was if they explained the footwork behind the punches.  I also thought they should have stressed control in punching techniques, but that is just me.  The purpose of the video is to exercise, not to train someone to be in the ring.The exercises in the video range from slow and easy to fast and complex.  As with any new activity, learning the moves takes time.  The first few times, I definitely felt like I was messing everything up and felt uncoordinated.  I still feel a bit on the uncoordinated side, but it is getting better.Does this video motivate me?  To be honest, I find the instructors too cheery for my taste.  As with most videos, the participants seem to be tight and well muscled.  There are a few token large people like me, but they are in the back and largely unseen IMHO.I do think the video provides a decent workout for the average person.  I find that I am quite tired as the video was nearing the end and to be honest.Overall, RIPPED seems to be a decent exercise video.  It is now something I have incorporated into my exercise routine and incorporate it once or twice a week.
summary: Decent Exercise Routine For The Average Person
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: This one really got me sweating.  The routines were not impossible to do for a beginner, though my coordination needs to improve.  The motivational comments during the exercises were cheesy, but I appreciate good cheese.  My only negative comments are that they should have had the lady doing the modified (less intense) exercises for us neophytes closer to the center so we could see what she was doing or included those modified routines in the tutorials.  Overall, I found the workout to be useful and this is a routine that I will incorporate in my exercise plan as a change of pace once or twice per week.
summary: Tough for a beginner, but a good place to start
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I wasn't familiar with the RIPPED workouts before I received this DVD, but I love home workouts, and own 300+ workout DVDs.  The level of this is perfect for intermediate exercisers.The workout is a full-body workout, and by the time you finish it, you'll have worked each body part.  It comes in a 48 minutes long, and is broken down into smaller segments.  There is also a tutorial you can watch for each segment.  (Other reviews have broken down the segments, so I won't do so here.)The pacing on this isn't too fast, and the instructors give nice form pointers throughout the workout.While I liked this workout after doing it once, it doesn't have a lot of "fun factor" to me.  The music was just bland (and so next time I'll play my own music), and some of the phrases that get repeated are a bit cheesy.  The background exercisers also seem to have a bit of the Stepford Wives fakeness going on.Overall, this one isn't bad, but there are other workouts that I would rather use.  It would be good, though, if you're looking for something at the intermediate level to throw into your rotation every now and again.
summary: Nice intermediate-level workout, but not a lot of "fun factor"
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: Let me first say that I was lucky most of my life in that I didn't have to exercise or DIDN'T exercise until 50.  I was in relatively good shape just hiking or keeping up with the kids.  Then...life happens.  The metabolism slows, age sets in and you quit all of your bad habits and weight starts packing on.  Ok, I caught it before then but a few pounds did get past my radar.  I will admit that people get in really good shape for different reasons.  This seems to me to be for one of those times. I stay in shape by a mile or so a day walking program (Leslie Sansone).I tried this DVD many times but really never made it past the warm up. But for the sake of the review I TRIED to do it and did have my 15 yr old granddaughter do it.  This is what we determined.This whole DVD is extreme to me.  There is a bonus abs section but it is a standing up abs workout. This DVD mentions a diet plan but that is on a website. There is alot of sharp and edgy music and that keeps the spirit up for 48 minutes and help you not realize you might need to spend the rest of the day in bed.This dvd is NOT for the beginner but my granddaughter enjoyed some of it and didn't have a problem doing it.  It is like everything else...you probably can't do it in its entirety for many months, maybe a year. There are options for daily use.  At the beginning of each section there is an option to do the section with a tutorial so that you don't spend the whole time trying to figure out  the routine.  I really liked that option. Each exercise has a person that does it in a less extreme way just in case you can't keep up how they would like you to do the exercise of the minuteI will keep doing the warm up until I find that it gets easier and maybe then I can tackle main DVD.  The one thing I don't like about DVD's of this type is that all of people doing the DVD's on the program are between 20 and 30.  My program that I do daily has people of all ages and that gives me the confidence to keep going.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: As you can see from a lot of my other reviews, I really like to review exercise DVDs as I am an avid exerciser.  Any workout that states you can burn up to 700 calories is one that I will at least try.  I am very glad that I tried RIPPED, the one stop body shock.  The workout is short, it is 48 minutes, and you can add a 5 minute ab workout at the end if you like.The dance sections and plyometric sections are very hard.  Even though I am in shape, I am not coordinated, and had a hard time following the moves.  The modifications that were shown were very helpful, and the second time I did the DVD I had a much easier time with these moves.  Most DVDs recommend that you watch the entire DVD workout before you attempt to do the workout, this one does, and I should have heeded that advice as I would have had a much easier time exercising the first time.In my opinion, the workout sections are harder than the weight training sections.  However, that could be to me because I chose to use fairly light weights for this workout.Both Tina and Terry are motivating.  Tina is a little more wordy in her encouragement, and Terry tends to get down to business.I have already done this workout twice. This DVD fitness routine is definitely a keeper.
summary: Yummy workout routine, designed to break plateaus
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: If you are looking for one workout that will cover everything, this is worth looking at.  The target group for this is beginners to intermediates.  This requires some dumb bells or resistance bands.  Each segment of R.I.P.P.E.D is covered as a separate section (resistance training (7 minutes), intervals (5 minutes), power (10 minutes), plyometrics (5 minutes) and endurance (10 minutes)).  There is a warm up and a cool down.  Before each segment is an instructional tutorial.  There is an option to play the workout with or without the tutorial. There are beginner to advanced modifications for all exercises and low impact options are presented.The exercises themselves are a lot of solid tried and true standards with some innovative moves fit in. While they claim that you will burn 700 calories I doubt very few people will burn actually 700 calories doing this workout.  Maybe if you are 6 foot four inches and over 200 lbs but most people won't burn that kind of calories with this workout.Cueing on this video could be better.  The instructors can be a little chatty.  These are minor points and I think the overall merits of the workout are enough to bring it up to 4 stars. This would be a good video for someone who only wants to own a few DVDs and who wants to cover everything in a workout.  This is not quite as hard as a Jillian Michaels workout but it is still a solid workout if you are an advanced beginner to intermediate.  If you are looking for something like insanity or p90x, this may be too easy for you.
summary: Total body workout for advanced beginners to intermediates
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: Got this for me and my boyfriend to work out in the house.  It is a nice workout which you can modify to suit your level of fitness.  They show you modified moves to make it harder or easier and it does get your blood pumping.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I always tell people, your body is the original computer.  It knows what it needs and compensates for what it is not getting.  Conversely, when you are working out, if you do the same routine most days.your body gets used to it and there are diminishing returns.  This video is one routine.This might be good if you want to use it once a week instead of going to the gym.Additionally, most of these workout programs are more reliant on you change of diet than you working out.  I.e. by doing this workout does not mean you can have that doughnut.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: It's not super exciting or original and it doesn't have multiple work outs-you do the one 48 minute workout over and over.  I understand that is how a work-out video goes, but I was hoping there would be more on it than just the one.  Also, I've read other reviews that said the husband and wife team were annoying, I sort of agree with that-they seem a little fake and peppy, so if you want an angry trainer to yell for your motivation, this one isn't for you.  Overall, the work out is good, but not terribly original and not something I want to do day after day b/c it's always the same, with no additional content/variety.
summary: not the worst, but not the best either
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: R.I.P.P.E.D. stands for Resistance, Intervals, Power, Plyometrics, Endurance, and Diet and nutrition (also included are 2 extra 5 minute segments: Cool Down and Bonus Abs). Each segment is broken up in 5-10 minute intervals. The purpose of this is to "teach" the upcoming moves in each section. Unlike other fast-paced workout videos, R.I.P.P.E.D. takes the time to explain the different strength and endurance exercises at a slower pace to give you practice before you are thrown into the actual workout. I appreciated the breaks because it gave me a little time to cool down and also helped to increase my confidence before attempting the actual workout. During each segment, there are a variety of activity levels shown for you to follow, from beginner to advanced. Not all the people in the video are in amazing shape, which again, helped to build my confidence. The video runs 48 mins (including the cool down) which might seem like a long video but it went by really quickly and each section was manageable for a beginner like me. I was quite surprised with the quality of the video, workouts, trainers (Terry and Tina Shorter), and music. Terry and Tina have an infectious positive attitude and it helped to motivate me to continue pushing myself. I really enjoyed the cool down portion where Terry teaches some Tai Chi moves (Tai Chi is said to help reduce stress). I thought it added a wonderful tone to the workout. I give this video 5 starts for the variation in possible intensities, instructional portions, types of workouts, and positive vibes.
summary: Beginner and advanced workout for all!
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I had fun with this and it kept my interest because of the amount of variety in the workout.  It has many unique (and challenging) exercises.  It's on the tough side even if you are a regular exerciser, because it's not the "same ol' stuff" you probably normally do.  I was interested to read in the other reviews that this class is also taught in gyms -- it makes me hope that there will be further installments in the series!
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I have a lot of experience with exercise videos.  I've been watching them since Jane Fonda came out with her famous one in the 80s.  I'm not looking for the magic pill but I do want something that will keep me pressing play every day, at least for a while.  I thought this would be a grunt-work production for guys but it's quite friendly.  The instruction might be the best I've seen, they pay very close attention to good form -- almost to the point of slowing down the workout.  The instruction however, is like mini-commercials in between the workouts, and not a part of the workout itself. This way you can either skip over it or get some water.I actually got this for my husband and for myself I purchased a more basic strength training DVD, but I really like this one and I'm going to use this instead!
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: By now, everybody knows about the R.I.P.P.E.D. program! It's an intensive workout set designed to exercise your body with optimal caloric burning.HOWEVER... not everybody is able to locate a gym where you can find the R.I.P.P.E.D. program. If that's your case (it is mine!), then this DVD is for you. In a nutshell, it is the closest you can get to a live session. It basically trains you with the same routine exercises and everything works great. Just pop the DVD into your player, pump up the volume on your TV or stereo and let it go!It took me one session to get the feeling I have never done such a great workout session at the gym.RECOMMENDED!
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I've seen this guy in other fitness videos we've done so we thought we'd see what he had to offer.  The preview I saw looked good but unfortunately the flow is awful.  They are trying to cram too much in without allowing you to learn the moves first before quickly moving on.  I do Turbo Fire, P90X and similar workouts so I'm not a newbie to choreographed workouts.  The way this is edited doesn't make it feel like a cohesive workout and allows your heart rate to drop.  I'm glad others seem to like it so much but I wish I could send this one back.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I love trying new exercise DVDs so I was excited that  this was offered as part of the VINE program.  I have completed partial portions of the DVD on 2 separate occasions.  It is hard to finish the DVD because the moves are not unique and the music seems pretty good but the exercises are not geared towards the music.  What makes the DVD especially annoying though is the SMILING guy and the "jamming" guy in the back.  I don't know why the men felt the need to act like idiots in the dvd. Exercisers have to watch the DVD everyday, thus, the smiling guy and the jamming guy are just annoying distractions.  On another note, this was the confusing part to me: the ADVANCED exerciser looked in OKAY shape, while the modified exerciser was in OUTSTANDING shape.  I kept getting confused; I was looking to the outstanding lady to do the advanced moves but they had her doing the modifications.  To give you an idea of what I mean: Imagine you are at a martial arts class with Billy Blanks (TAEBO) and Richard Simmons.  Instead of Billy Blanks teaching you the advanced moves, Richard Simmons ends up showing the advance moves; that would cause confusion.  Clearly, Richard's body doesn't look like he does advanced moves of anything.Anyway...I don't want to do this DVD again; the smiling guy upsets me just thinking about doing this DVD.Update: I left my usual DVD at work.  I did this DVD again and the ENDURANCE section was just boxing moves and more burpies on the floor.  The plyo moves were just side jumps.  I found the best section to be the resistance section, where you do arm moves with light weights.  The DVD is simply not that great or interesting.
summary: The DVD was okay, but I am choosing not to put it in my rotation.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I have done the routine several times now.It really is a very challenging, whole body workout.  It is fast without much time internal to the routine for recovery between events, and the stretching and cool down are limited.  It takes 38 minutes from start to finish if you do the routine without the introductions and tutorials, and I recommend you watch them at least the first time through.This video is better for the limber, young crowd than a middle aged one.The workout is done by a husband and wife team (both in phenomenal shape).  The music is definitely geared toward the 20 something crowd.You can tell that elements of P90X and Insanity have been integrated into the routine.  The hosts even use some of the same language when describing exercises and techniques.This is a slicker appearance than either P90X or Insanity.  Everyone appearing in R.I.P.P.E.D. is in identical outfits to include the socks and shoes.  Everyone is smiling all the time, and the host makes a point of singing along to the workout music at several points.My feelings about this product are mostly good, but I don't recommend it for the 40+ crowd.  P90X is a better choice for the middle age crowd looking for an intense workout.  P90X spends a lot of time going through variations and modifications.  R.I.P.P.E.D. is fast and intense, and I believe that you could get great results if you kept up with it.  R.I.P.P.E.D. spends less time going over variations, and the modifications shown are significant.  For example, everyone else is doing jump squats, and the exemplar is flexing her knees.For the college crowd, this would be a great workout to mix things up.In service,Rich
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I am a home body exercise person: too hectic of a life to join the gym and get any value from such a membership.  hence,  I am always on a lookout for an exercise dvd to create a variety and reduce the boredom when you have to exercise at home.As a stand alone this is a a good energy and beat and another slant to an 'all body' exercise, or isolated if you have limited time.  the instructions are clear and they demonstrator is fun and encouraging.  The word RIPPED should not put you off if you already like Jillian Michael's dvds ..it is much the same level.  if you want burn energy and tone without heavy weights or afraid of bulking up .. this is a nice alternative to the domination that Jillian Michael's has for women-stay-at-exercise bod.  i would recommend this, but you might still pick the Jillian Michael's dvd for it structure.
summary: a lot tougher than I thought
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I rated RIPPED total body challenge 4 stars because it is a good workout. I like the ability to choose different sections I want to work on. Tina seems like a great personal trainer, very encouraging and easy is to understand and follow.Power is led by Terry and Polymetrics is led by Tina. The foot work on Polymetrics are tricky, I still haven't mastered them.Definitely not the same workout intensity as P90x but a decent workout and not as intimidating.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewerName: Trish "A Sun Salutin', Crochet Hookin' Chick!"
reviewText: I was very optimistic after reading the back cover of this DVD.  As a certified AFAA Group Exercise Instructor, I try to choose DVD instructors based on their certifications, past knowledge and/or reviews.  I have a library of over 100 fitness DVD' s and it seems that non-certified instructors seem to be popular, but their teaching methods are sometimes not safe  and sometimes dangerous.I appreciate instructors who teach proper form, safe techniques and are concerned for different levels of exercisers. The two instructors on this DVD make sure to teach with safety and proper form in mind.  This is not an "easy" DVD, but modifications are provided for beginners.The workout starts with a 5-minute warm up which begins with non-jarring movement to slowly raise body temperature and heart rate.The next segment is an upper body resistance training work out using medium weight. They concentrate on biceps, triceps, and shoulders. (7 minutes)The next 4 cardio/strength segments are a variety of interesting moves.  I was pleased to find a few new moves that I had not seen on any other DVD.1.  Intervals (5 minutes) - This segment included jump rope (no rope), squats, jumping jacks, etc.  Each movement had modifiers for high impact moves.2.  Power (10 minutes)  Using heavy to medium weights for part, you will perform squats, burpees, mountain climbers, standing reverse flys etc3.  Plyometrics (5 minutes) This segment included squats, Jumps with directional changes, lunges, walking cross-overs, etc., all with high impact and low impact options.4.  Endurance (10 minutes) All cardio, no weights, heart rate up! Kickboxing moves, oblique twists, etc.5.  Cool Down (5 minutes) Slow movements and stretches.6. Bonus Abs (5 minutes) Very interesting standing an routine using a towel. I would do this on it's own after another workout--loved it!Overall a great DVD with the ability to play the entire workout or use the customization options for a shorter workout.Highly recommended for all levels.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: R.I.P.P.E.D." stands for resistance, intervals, power, plyometrics, endurance, and diet and nutrition.Features:1) It has a tutorial demonstrating proper form and technique.2) The moves are simple yet effective3) The workout is combined with original music.4) It acts as a cardiovascular workout for the whole body.5) In order to facilitate quick workouts, the segments are broken into parts6) There is also an abs workout segment as a bonus feature.7) It is well executed, easy to follow, and is true as it claims to be.Pros:1) It is an intense workout and helps in burning the body fat and calories and thus getting toned.2) In just five workout segments with warm-up and cooldown one can burn more than 700 calories within an hour3) It targets the upper body, strengthening the core muscles, back, legs, and glutes.
summary: Helps in strengthening the core muscles and getting toned
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge

reviewText: I tried this video and say just save your money and go with the Jillian Michaels videos you can find on prime. This was an OK workout, nothing too special or exciting.
Title: R.I.P.P.E.D. Total Body Challenge
